titlestmt.titleproper: Guide to the Italian Castle Archive
titlestmt.author: by Mark W. Rabuck

publicationstmt.publisher: Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library

did.unittitle: Italian castle archive

repository.corpname: Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library

did.abstract:
The collection contains over 2,000 short manuscripts and printed documents including news bulletins, diplomatic reports, histories, letters, scholarly and practical treatises, legal records, broadsides, genealogies, sermons and orations, plays, and poems. It is especially rich in material concerning the diplomatic role of the Papal States during the War of the Spanish Succession; reports on papal conclaves, instructions to nuncios, and letters from the College of Cardinals; and items pertaining to Ancona, Naples, and the D'Aste family. Other well-documented individuals and events include Innocent X; Olimpia Maidalchini-Pamphili; Queen Christina of Sweden; Cardinal Mazarin; Louis XIV; controversies concerning the Jesuits; the siege of Vienna in 1683 and the 1701 revolt against the Spanish crown in Naples; natural disasters; and the extention of papal authority.
In addition, the collection also contains a number of treatises, including works on alchemy, astronomy, cartography, military science, numerology, law, philosophy, and rhetoric, as well as an eight volume edition of the works of the physicist Paretus, and numerous satires on prominent individuals.

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition
acqinfo.p: Gift of H. P. Kraus, with one subsequent purchase.

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use
userestrict.p: The Italian Castle Archive is the physical property of the Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library, Yale University. Literary rights, including copyright, belong to the authors or their legal heirs and assigns. For further information, consult the appropriate curator.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Italian Castle Archive. General Collection, Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: The materials are open for research.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This collection consists of 106 volumes, dating from c. 1550 to 1770 (with one volume containing items from as late as 1848). Five numbers in the sequence (10, 23, 59, 69, and 77) are missing, and two additional numbers (50a and 98a) have been added. Seven numbers are multi-volume sets. The collection totals 119 volumes in all. Most of the volumes are collections of short manuscripts and printed documents pertaining to a variety of topics. Over 2,000 items are present, about 1,550 in manuscript and roughly 500 in print. All of the documents are on paper and are bound in contemporary vellum. While most of the manuscript documents are written in an italic cursive, a few examples of broad humanist script are present in the collection. A fair number of engravings, woodcuts, ink drawings, and watercolors supplement the text documents.

The entire Italian Castle Archive was donated to Yale by H. P. Kraus, with the exception of volume 98a, which was purchased from Kraus in 1991. The earlier provenance of the Archive is unknown, although the frequent mention of Naples and the D'Aste family leads one to believe that the compilation of the Archive was completed in Southern Italy in the mid to late eighteenth century. Supporting this claim are frequent references to Ancona (where Cardinal Marcello D'Aste was Archbishop in the early 18th century) and Switzerland (where Marcello D'Aste served as Papal Nuncio from 1692-1695). Another member of the family, Donato Antonio D'Aste (d. 1743), was a famous legal scholar who resided in Naples. However, the wide array of documents and the lack of clear early provenance leave the origin of the Archive a mystery. Most of the documents in the collection are from Italy, with a small percentage coming from Spain, France, and the Empire. A vast majority of the items are in Italian and Latin with a few documents in Spanish and French also present. A large number of early printed documents and broadsides may be found in the collection, many of them from the Stamperia Reverendae Camerae Apostolicae. Of the manuscript items, there are some original autograph documents (most notably one of Pope Clement XI, Vol. 29, No. 33a), but most are contemporary copies. Among formal treatises and histories are many letters, news bulletins, and diplomatic reports. There are also a fair number of plays and poems on various topics.

The collection is especially rich in primary source material for the era of the War of Spanish Succession (1700-1713), especially in regards to the role of the Papacy and the Italian peninsula in that conflict. Several volumes contain detailed reports from Papal Conclaves, demonstrating the process by which new Popes were elected from the late Middle Ages to the eighteenth century. There are many sets of instructions to Papal Nuncios, providing an interesting glimpse into the diplomatic relations between the Apostolic See and France, Spain, Portugal, Switzerland, Poland, Flanders, the Austrian Empire, and the various states of Italy.

Series of documents within the collection provide sources and background for a number of influential individuals from the period: Cardinal Mazarin; Queen Christina of Sweden; Olimpia Maidalchini-Pamphili, sister-in-law to Pope Innocent X; King Philip V of Spain; Pope Clement XI; and King Louis XIV of France. Many letters from the Sacred College of the Cardinals provide insight into the politics which surrounded the Papacy in the seventeenth and eighteenth centuries. Certain events are also well-documented within the collection: the readmission of the Jesuits into Venice; the controversy over Jesuit missionaries in China; the 1701 revolt of Naples against the Spanish crown; the 1683 defeat of the Turks at Vienna; various tensions between Pope Alexander VII and the French King Louis XIV; the decline of the De'Medici family of Tuscany; a confrontation between Jesuits and Dominicans at the University of Douai (Flanders) in 1591; and the emergence of the Duchy of Savoy as a player in world politics.

A number of scholarly and practical treatises on a wide variety of topics exist in the collection. These include ones on numerology, alchemy, astronomy, military science, cartography, rhetoric, philosophy, Aristotle, law, history, varnish-making, and equine medicine. There are two student notebooks on the subject of rhetoric, one from the Jesuit College of Rome. Specific histories are given for the cities of Venice, Pisa, Genoa, and Florence, and for the Roman Church. The collection contains an eight volume edition of the works of Paretus, who wrote works on physics soon after Newton, which contain anatomical drawings and a plan for a flying machine. Also present is a 1548 edition of Ptolemy with maps of the Americas added by the editor Giuseppe Moleto.
Other items of note in the collection include:
--Reports and poems about natural disasters such as earthquakes, hailstorms, and a 1660 eruption of Mt. Vesuvio.
--Various treatises and broadsides in support of and against the extention and preservation of Papal authority.
--Poems on subjects which range from the elegaic to the scatalogical.
--Numerous satires--in drama, mock-epic, and verse--of prominent individuals of the period.
--An entrance examination to a Jesuit's German and Hungarian College in Rome.
--Several documents and engravings concerning drama and specific theaters in Rome.
--Watercolor paintings of plans for a fireworks display in Ferrara and of the Battle of Chiari (1701).
--A dictionary of legal terms.
--Records of legal procedings for several cases of murder, heresy, and conspiracy, plus several records of duels, assassinations, and executions.
--Administrative documents of several Nuncios and parish churches.
--Several family histories and genealogical charts.
--Numerous sermons and orations.
--Several reports on Constantinople and accounts of relations with the Ottoman Empire.
--A prayer for lawyers, asking for more arguments and lawsuits.

did.unittitle: GLI HONESTI PENSIERI

Gli Honesti Pensieri. Comedy in five acts. Manuscript. 1 leaf, 115 ff., 1 leaf. (Piece of title page missing, name of author crossed out on title; inscription on end leaf crossed out.) Small 4to. Original limp vellum. (Naples?, c. 1620).

A comedy, probably by a follower of Giovanni Battitsta Della Porta (c. 1538-1615). The inscription on the last leaf is still partly readable: "Per ordine del Sr. Gia. Ant. Basilio da Bari orata per me Sciptione Cardassi in Servicio del..."
MISCELLANY

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Contemporary limp vellum. Italy (Naples?), c. 1660.

did.unittitle: Hec Dies quam fecit Dominus exultemus et letemur in ea. Draft for a sermon in Italian. 4 pp.
St. Matthew 10. Draft of a sermon in Italian, with quotations in Latin. 2-1/2 pp.
Himnus hic dat modum vitae, Quo utuntur Jesuitae. Burlesque Latin hymn in Goliardic style, making fun of the Jesuits' love for plentiful food and drink. 3 pp.
Oratorio Procuratora. Latin prayer of an attorney. 5 lines, wishing for a perrenial supply of quarrels, lawsuits, etc.
Mount Vesuvio, Eruption in July 1660. Hour by hour observation of the eruption of Mt. Vesuvio that took place from July 3-July 10, 1660. 8 pp.
Ferrara, Francesco, and Francesco Antonio Scatola. Correspondence concerning poetry, with quotations from Petrarch, Boccaccio, Bemo, etc. In the beginning, Ferrara's sonnet to Scatola. 54 pp.
Canto Primo. 71 octave stanzas of a poem, constituting the first canto. In the manner of G.B. Marino (1569-1625). 36 pp.
Joachimus, Abbot of Fiore. Trattato de operibus sexti temporis. Excerpts from chapter 23, on the Prophet Isaiah. Gioacchino da Fiore (c. 1130-1202) is mentioned in Dante's Divine Comedy. 2 pp.
Iconography of Popes. Interpretations in Latin and descriptions in Italian of a set of allegoriacal representations of various popes. 24 pp.

Alphabetum mysteriosum. Consists of a schematic drawing of the "mysterious alphabet" with explanations and calculations (2 pp.); a list of interpretations of the designations and coats-of-arms of various popes, with biographical data (26 pp.); Archbishop Malachias' prophecies De Pontificibis in the interpretation of Alfonso Ciacconi, a Dominican (2 pp.); and instructions on how to use the Alphabetum in order to determine the length of time a pope stayed in office (1 p.). 31 pp. (some tears).
Astrampsychi Somniorum Interpretatio. A Latin list of dreams and their significance. "Astrampsychos" was the name given to priests and magi of ancient Egypt and Persia. 5-1/2 pp.

Nicephorus, Patriarch of Constantinople. Interpretamenta somniorum. Dreams and their significance. Written in Latin Iambic verse and arranged alphabetically. A Greek-Latin version of the Interpramenta Bibliotheca Classica Latina , vol. 129. 8-1/2 pp.

Ahmad ibn Sirin. Oneirocritica Praefatio, et Somniorum Interpretatio. Excerpts from a Latin translation of a comprehensive work on dream interpretation by the 9th century Arab physician Ahmad ibn Sirin (Ahmed Abu Mazar) which was translated into Latin, Greek, French, and Italian. The Latin edition was published in Frankfurt by Wechel in 1577 with the title Apomasaris Apotelesmata ; and a Greek-Latin edition Oneirocritica was published in Paris in 1603, together with Artemidorus' work on dreams. 114 pp.

Kabbalah numerica, id est Arti de numeri. An interesting treatise on numeric Kaballah; the art of numbers is treated with chapters on pyramids of summations and partition, on arches of numbers, etc. A Fransiscan monk, Joannes Bernardinus, is quoted on leaf 1 verso and leaf 37 recto. 94 pp. (47 leaves) with tables and diagrams.
NUMEROLOGICAL MISCELLANY

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: stated). Contemporary vellum. Italy, 17th century.

did.unittitle: Li modi di leggere la zifra. Treatise in Italian on cabalistic numerology. 18 leaves.
Oraculus Cabalisicus. Table of letters and numbers from which to calculate the election of Pope Innocent X (1644-1655). Table of 1 page.
De cuspidibus de Horoscopo. Treatise in Latin on the significance of the Zodiac signs. Table and 9 leaves.
Ludus Numerorum. Treatise in Latin on numerology, with cabalistic and astrological implications. Chapters I-IV. 10 leaves. 8vo.
(Numerological Tables). Folio folded to 4to.

Papiniano da Villanova. Libro della Geomantia. An Italian treatise on divination. The author could not be identified by Thorndike (vol. IV, p. 473), who places him in the 16th century and locates one manuscript of this treatise in the Vatican Library (Vatic. Reg. Suev. 1319). It was apparently never printed. 156 leaves.
COLLECTION OF POEMS

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: vellum. Italy, 17th and 18th centuries.

did.unittitle: Instruzione Per La Vita Civile di un Giovane Nobile. 17 leaves. Didactic Italian poem in blank verse, giving instructions for the conduct of life to a young nobleman.

Nappini, Bartolomeo (called Polipodio Calabro). 24 poems, 20 leaves, (foliated 18-37). Poems by the Calabrian poet Bartolomeo Nappini (d. 1717), who wrote under the pseudonym Polipodio Calabro, consisting of 20 sonnets, 2 elegies, 1 poem (in praise of the pig) in tercets, and one satirical poem. The poems are done in the "stile pedantesco," also known as the "stile fidenziano," which forces the pedantic Latin jargon of schoolmasters upon the Italian language. The last edition of Nappini's poems came out at Guastalla in 1780 and it is a bibliographical rarity.
Il Dottor Boccaleone Consola Valerio Notaro esser gli morta la Moglie & Figli. 7 leaves, numbered ff. 38-44. Italian canzone of 37 octave stanzas, possibly also by Bartolomeo Nappini.
(Consiglio dell'Oracolo in Prendere Moglier). 1 page (f. 45). A humorous oracle as guidance in selecting a wife.

Regali Lasciati ad un Amico nella Partenza. 10 leaves, numbered ff. 46-55. Parting from Rome, the (anonymous) author describes in humorous verses the presents he leaves behind for a friend, a theme reminiscent of Francois Villon's Grand Testament .
L'Ignoranza Escaldada.--Racconto (se che fece un grazioso Pittore). 2 leaves, numbered ff. 56-57. Two canzone, extolling ignorance; a rough paraphrase from the prophet Habakkuk.
Fortuna e Fato. 2 leaves, numbered ff. 58-59. Two sonnets and several poems on the subject of fortune and fate; includes excerpts from Matteo Bojardo, G.B. Guarini, and an epigram by Ausonius.
Fugacita dell Vita Umana. 3 pages, numbered ff. 60-61. Poem in rhymed quartets on the fleetingness of human life.
De Sogni. 2 pages, numbered ff. 62. A poem on dreams, in blank verse ("Verso sciolto").

Chocolata.--Della Chocolata.--Colmenero de Ledesma, Antonio. 13 leaves, numbered ff. 64-67. Two early poems on chocolate, one in Latin, the other in Italian. At the end is an excerpt from the first Italian edition of Colmenero's treatise on chocolate (1667; Palau 56907). Colmenero da Ledesma, a Spanish physician, was the first to write a monograph (1631) on chocolate, the drink made from cocoa beans that had come to Europe from Mexico. Only in the early part of the 18th century did chocolate become a fashionable beverage in Europe.
Le Vignate. 11 leaves, numbered ff. 77-87. Italian poem in Anacreontic verse on the delight of autumn in the countryside.

Volpe, Conte della. All'Eminentissimo Principe Il Signor Cardinal Conti per la Nascita del secondo Nipote. 1 page, numbered ff. 88. The poem to Cardinal Conti is signed Cleogene Naffio, the name given to Volpe as a member of the Academy Arcadia. It is dated Rome, 1729. This Conte della Volpe seems not to be one of the famous brothers Volpe who were active in Padua at this time and established the Tipographia Volpi-Cominiano.
Copia del Memoriale dato a Il Sig. Papa Clemente XII. Corsini. 3 leaves, numbered ff. 89-91. Copy of a memorandum, in the form of a poem in tercets, to Pope Clement XII (1730-1740).
In Lode del Porco. (In Lode del Prosciutto). 9 pages, numbered ff. 92-96. A poem in Anacreontic style in praise of a pig (8 pages), followed by a sonnet on a delicious ham.

L'Imperator Carlo V fa pigliare un Faccino. 3 leaves, numbered ff. 97-98. A satirical canzone on the Emperor Charles V who was put to shame by the sense of justice of a drunken porter whom he had brought to the royal palace.
Sonetto Peripatetica. -Enigma Paripatetica. 2 pages, numbered ff. 100. Two "peripatetic" sonnets in the grotesque style of Burchellio (1400-1449).

A Monsignor...de Brevi, che promise cert'assagio di vini precosi. 6 leaves, numbered ff. 101-105. A canzone in praise of wine, with the refrain "Monsignor quel vino aspetto," dedicated to a Monsignor de Brevi who had promised the author to let him taste precious wines. On the last page is a drinking song of wandering students (goliards).

Bella Dona richiede ad un Cacciatore, un Augellino, ed egli cosi risponde. -La Corte. -Grazioissima risoluzione, 1690. -Ad un Marchese che portova la Carozza con certi Cavalli. -Epitaffio alla Sepoltura del Colangeli. 5 pages, numbered ff. 106-108. 5 sonnets in a burlesque style, reminiscent of Berni, on various events and persons in Rome.
Gloria, et Honore...della Santita di Nostro Sig. Papa Clemente XI, Anno 1714. 1 page (f. 108 verso). Sonnet in praise of Pope Clement XI (1700-1721).

Al Serenissimo Eugenio di Savoia per La Disfatta de Turchi in Ungheria li 5 Agosto 1716. 2 pages, (f. 109). Two sonnets in praise of Prince Eugene of Savoy and his victory over the Turks. By Don Angelo Ricci (?).
Capitolo della Zappa. 4 leaves, numbered ff. 110-113. A burlesque poem in tercets on the hoe; in imitation of the style of Berni.
All'Indiscretezza del Padre Ciceri. 4 leaves, numbered ff. 110-113. A burlesque poem in tercets ("capitolo"), ridiculing a friar, dated 1712.

Ringraziamento per 4 Fiaschi di Vino. -per dieci Fiaschi di Vino. -(Una Giavane si Lamenta...un marito troppo veccio). -All Abbati Montani...Un Cane rubba certa carne di mano. -Impostura all'autore. 3 leaves, numbered ff. 118-120. Six humorous sonnets; thanking for bottles of wine; an 18 year old girl married to a 67 year old husband (referring to a "true story" of 1744), etc.

La Birba. -Dorme Spensierato. -Amante che scuopre L'Amore alla sua Donna. -Notturna Serenata. 7 leaves, numbered ff. 121-127. Three popular songs and one sonnet. The song La Birba (The Scoundrel) has a choral refrain "Eviva La Birba e Chi L'invento"; the two other songs are sung after the same melody as La Birba . The texts only are given. The sonnet is reminiscent and seems to anticipate the style of Guiseppe Belli (1791-1863), the greatest poet in Roman dialect.
Alli Virtuosi Tabbacanti. 2-1/2 pages, numbered ff. 128-129. One sonnet, "scherzo Poetico," and epigrams in Latin, Spanish, and Italian on tobacco and taking snuff.
Consiglio ad un Amico. 1 page (fol. 129 verso). A sonnet, based on a quotation from Cicero, advising to consult the wisdom of the past.
Sogno, accaduto nel Mese di Luglio 1746. 28 leaves, numbered ff. 130-157. A long poem of a dream. At the end a note stating that this poem is "un Compendio Teorico della Guerre di 10 Anni."

El Genio Romanesco. -In Laude Nicolai Salvii. 2 pages, numbered ff. 158. Italian sonnet and a Latin poem in praise of the architect Nicola Salvi, creator of the Fontana di Trevi. Both poems are dated 1744. Salvi's fountain, begun in 1732, was finished only in 1762. The style of the sonnet is similar to that of the great poet in Roman dialect, G.G. Belli.

Sopra ad un Podagroso. -Rimedio per guerir La Podagra. 5 pages, numbered ff. 159-161. Two humorous poems on gout; a canzone, with the refrain "Simonelli ha la Podagra," and a sonnet on the cure of the gout.
Procura trouvare un'Innamorata. 1 page (f. 161 verso). A sonnet on the difficulty of finding a sweetheart to one's taste.
De Ducenda Uxore. 2 pages (f. 162). Two satirical poems on marriage; Latin distychs in the style of Ovid and the Italian sonnet.

Ottave giocose Sopra Le Moroide. -Rimedio per Le Moroide, La Vendetta. 8-1/2 pages, numbered ff. 163-167. Humorous poems on hemorrhoids and their cure, the latter referring to Simone Maiolo's Dies Caniculares.
La Forza del Destino. 1 page (f. 167 verso). A sonnet.
La Vendemnia. 5 pages, numbered ff. 168-170. A long poem (text for a song) on vintage time, with the choral refrain "Alla Mozza Donne belle."
Consiglio agli Ammogliati. 1 page (f. 170 verso). A sonnet of advice to married people.
La Caccia. -Quest'è L'estrema volta Ingrata Pastorella. -La Vite overo Autunno. 2 leaves, numbered ff. 171-172. Three pastoral songs: on the hunt; a lover's lament; on the delights of autumn.
Ottave sopra alcune spose. 2 pages (f. 173). Four stanzas, each with a moral ("senso") on married women.
Poeta assistente per la Festa di S. Luigi Gonzaga alla musica nella Chiesa di S. Ignazio...ricordandosi si S. Romualdo Monaco Benedettino... 1 page, numbered fol. 173 (bis). An anti-Jesuit sonnet.

Grimaldi, Stefano. Del gran Marte de i Re... 1 page (f. 173 bis, verso). Sonnet by the Genoese ambassador to the court of Louis XIV to a lady of the French court. On account of this sonnet, Grimaldi was banned from the court for a time.
Affetto et industria de Sorci. -Morale di Felicita. 1 leaf (f. 174). Two sonnets: one on mice, with all lines ending on the same rhyme; one on happiness.
La Chitarra. 5 leaves, numbered ff. 175-179. A humorous poem in tercets ("capitolo') on the guitar.
La disgrazie dell'Autore. 1 page (fol. 180 recto). Sonnet.
All'Abbate Montani. 1 page (fol. 180 verso). Sonnet to the Abbot Montani for his three sonnets on the occasion of the fiesta of San Spirito.

Narra l'Autore...del Terremoto in Roma. -Strozzi, Monsig. In occasione del Retroscritto Terremoto Sopra i Bucchari e Le Porcellane Belle... Per il Terremoto delli 2 Feb. an. 1703... 3 pages, numbered ff. 181-182. Three sonnets on the occasion of the earthquake in Rome, Jan. 14 and Feb. 2, 1703.
Panfili, Cardinal Benedetto. Il Giucco dell'Ombra bella pressa di Belgrado L'Anno 1716. 1 page (f. 182 verso). A sonnet on the occasion of Prince Eugene of Savoy's victory at Belgrade.
La Caccia. 4-1/2 pages, numbered ff. 183-185. A poem in Latin distychs on hunting.
Risponde, essendoli richiesto un Sonetto. 1 page, (f. 185 verso). An allegedly extemporized sonnet, done in imitation of a famous tour de force by Lope de Vega.
L'Arquebugio. 7 pages, numbered ff. 186-189. An Italian poem in tercets ("capitolo") on the arquebus, in the style of Berni.

Discreve L'Autore quante Cose prende uno que piglia Moglie. Prerogative il Padrone e il Servitore. -Si lagna della crudelta della sua Donna. -Ceremonie tra Parti. -Ceremonie tra il Padrone e il Servitore. -Si lagna della crudelta della sua donna. -Il Calesse. 6 pages, numbered ff. 189 (verso)-192 (recto). Six sonnets.
Descizione del Tempio di Gierusamemme. Sonnet. 1 page (f. 192 verso).

(Gregorini, Costanza.) -(Gigli, Girolama.) 2 pages (f. 193). 2 sonnets referring to true or legendary fates of lovers. The first sonnet describes an event that took place in 1714 and a note states that the unhappy lover, Costanza Gregorini, died in 1716.
Chi ognuno ha il suo Ramo di Pazzia. -L'Ignoranza. 2 pages (f. 194). Two sonnets.

Intermedio Primo. Il Monte della Pieta de Pegni. Intermedio 2. 13-1/2 pages, numbered ff. 195-201. Two theatrical dialogues (or duets?); the first between "Fidele" and a "Patrizio Giovane del Custode;" the other between "Maestro di Casa" and "Momo Cavamacchie."
Innamorato di Donna brutta. -Vien burlato per amar Donna piccola. 5 pages, numbered ff. 202-204. Two poems: one by the lover of an ugly woman; the other by one of a short woman.
Enimmi. -Aenigmata. With keys. 14 leaves text and 3 leaves keys, numbered ff. 205-223. 106 rhymed riddles in Italian and 15 Latin riddles, all with their solutions.
Ipocondrico. 1 page (f. 224 recto). A satirical sonnet on the hypochondriac.

Signor si sa comunemente omai... -Natura Immutabile di Sua Moglie. 2 pages (ff. 224 verso, 225 recto). Two sonnets, paraphrasing Latin quotations. The first sonnet has a note on the erudite Lucrezia Marinella .

Per sue Mogliera. -Un Giovanetto desidera un Maestro per bene apprendere La Lingua Latina. -Tornando di Rome ad abitar con La sua Moglie in Siena. 3 pages, numbered 224 verso-225. Three satirical sonnets.
Indice. 4 leaves, unnumbered. Table of contents for volume 4.
LETTERS AND DOCUMENTS

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: pages, numbered ff. 1-211 with a 4 page index. Folio. Contemporary limp vellum. Italy, 17th century.

did.unittitle: Index. 2 leaves.

Il Mercurio Postiglione da Quest'all'altro Mondo. 61 leaves, numbered ff. 1-60. A political satire in dialogue form. The interlocutors are Mercury, Mars, Juppiter, and Momus. Mercury, fictitious postman from Heaven, brings letters from Earth which receive biting comments from the gods. The tendency is anti- Spanish, very much in the tone of Tranio Boccalini's Ragguagli di Parnaso (1612).

The Mercurio postiglione was composed shortly after the victory of the Venetians over the Turkish fleet at Candia, in 1648. A work with the same title was published in 1667 in Vill-Franca by Claudio del Monte. The present ms. includes attacks against the Catholic Church, the Jesuits, and (on leaf 19 recto) against Queen Christina of Sweeden who is accused of choosing religion or heresy according to her convenience.

On leaves 31-32 is a purported letter to Louis XIV by a former mistress, supplanted by a rival, MMe. Lavalliere; on leaves 40-41, a machiavellian analysis of the Wentworth, first earl of Stratford (leaves 52-54); Mazarin to the Queen Mother of France (leaves 56-59) and comments on them (leaves 54 verso, 55 recto and verso, 59 verso, and 69 recto).

Relatione della Vita del Cardinal Mazzarino. 57 leaves, numbered ff. 65-121. An account of the life of the Cardinal Mazarin, with special emphasis on his youth, interspersed with interesting anecdotes, little known biographical details, etc., evidently written by someone who was acquainted with the Cardinal. Onleaf is an excellent summary of highlights of Mazarin's career.

Mazzarino, Guilio. Testamento del Sig. Cardin. Mazzarino. 22 leaves, numbered ff. 124-145. The will as set up in different stages between March 3 and 8, previous to Mazarin's death on March 9, 1661. The Bib. Nationale has 7 printed editions of the will, all published in 1663.

Ferdinand II of Hapsburg. Espozitione fatta in Collegio Veneto dal Residente Cesareo. -Risposta parte letta in Collegio al Residente Cesareo. Together 2 leaves, numbered ff. 146-147. A report, dated June 10, 1630, made to the Governing Board of the Republic of Venice by the diplomatic representative of the German Emperor, Ferdinand II, in regard to damage resulting from raids made by Imperial troops in Venetian territory. The report is followed by a reply from the Venetian government, dated June 12, 1630.
Readmission of the Jesuits into Venetian Territory. Six documents, 7 leaves together, numbered ff. 148- 155; present in copies:

(1) Alexander VII, Pope.
Breve di...Papa Alessandro settimo alla...Republica di Venetia. In Latin. Official letter of Pope Alexander VII to the Republic of Venice, dated November 23, 1656, pleading for the re-admission of the Jesuits into Venice on account of the usefulness of their religious and educational services. It is interesting to note that the letter precedes by one year the publication of the famous Jansenist attack on the Jesuits: the Provincial Letters of Pascal constituting the spearhead of this attack, published in 1657.

(2) Republic of Venice. Risposta della Republica di Venezia. The Republic of Venice grants the request made by Pope Alexander VII. The phrasing of the reply is very characteristic (leaf 151r.): "although many tenacious obstacles have been set up against this (the re-admission), and these obstacles in no time and under other pressure could be overcome...", etc.

(3) Pope Alexander VII. Breve di nostro Signore Papa Alessandre Settimo alla sudetta Republica di Venezia. In Latin. Official letter of the Pope, thanking the Republic of Venice for granting re- admission to the Jesuits.

(4) Juan de Lugo, Cardinal, S.J. Lettera del Padre General dei Gesuiti al Serenissimo Doge della Republica Veneta. Letter to the Doge of Venice, by Cardinal Juan of Lugo (1583-1660), General of the Jesuit Order. thanking him for the re-admission.

(5) __________, Altra del medesimo alla Republica di Venezia. Another letter, describing the grateful reaction of the Company to the favor granted by Venice, and expressing his regrets that he is unable to attend the re-instatement ceremony at Venice.

(6) Doge of Venice. Lettera del Doge di Venezia al Cardinal di Lugo. Letter, dated Feb. 3, 1657, expressing his happiness at issuing the decree concering the re-admission of the Jesuits. A printed collection of documents concerning the Jesuits in the Republic of Venice was published in 1873 by G. Cappelletti. (BM)

(Monaldeschi, Rinaldo, Marchese). Relazione della morte del Marchese Rinaldo Monaldeschi. -Risposta della relazione della morte. Together 9 leaves numbered ff. 155-163. A contemporary account of the execution of Rinaldo Monaldeschi, November 6, 1657, by order of Queen Christina of Sweeden whose lover he had been. Apparently Monaldeschi, formerly leader of the French party in Rome, had communicated to the Spanish government a plan which had been contrived by Queen Christina, in collusion with Mazarin. The plan contemplated the conquest of the Kingdom of Naples (at that time under Spanish rule) and the seating of Christina on the throne.

The author of the present ms. attributes Monaldeschi's disgrace and subsequent death to the hostility between him and the two Santinelli brothers, both members of Christina's entourage. In an anonymous letter to the Queen, M. discloses certain details of an offensive character to Christina's reputation which had earlier been confided to him by Ludovico Santinelli.

The author expresses his horror at Christina's decision to have Monaldeschi murdered by Santinelli himself. He adds details concerning the manner of the assassination (leaf 158) and criticizes Santinelli's behavior (leaf 160v). The reply to the above account, accusing its author of having overlooked the pivotal fact on which the assassination was based: Monaldeschi was betrayed rather than a traitor; his murder was an act neither of justice nor of political expediency. A printed account of the assassination appeared in 1662, under the authorship of Father Pierre Le Bel.

Christina, Queen of Sweeden. Copy of a letter to the Marchese Santinelli. 2 pages. Dated November 17, 1657. Some passages of the letter read as follows: "I didn't want to injure the credit you have with me by believing you capable of what he alone was capable of doing. He was the one who betrayed me, and he wanted me to believe that you were the traitor...Do not try to justify my action towards anyone; I intend to give an account of it to no-one but God...I know that I have acted in accordance with divine justice...Be sure that I shall support you."

(Monaldeschi, Rinaldo, Marchese). Pronostico della morte del Monaldeschi. 14 lines, fol 164v. A satirical sonnet written against Queen Christina of Sweeden. The poet compares Monaldeschi with his namesake in Tasso's Gerusalemme Liberata , and Christina to the sorceress Armida. A Latin distych follows.

Christina, Queen of Sweeden. Copies of two letters to the Marchese Santinelli. Together in two leaves, numbered ff. 165-166. The first letter, dated May 10, 1659, is a reply to a message from Santinelli from Vienna. Christina warns him against wasting money and time; she will not pay his expenses. "I speak frankly: think of your case and don't commit any blunder." In the second letter, Christina expresses her shock about Santinelli's flaunting the title ambassador at the Vienese court without her authorization. "I hereby decide to dismiss you from my service. I am thoroughly unwilling to authenticate your blunders with my protection."

Christina, Queen of Sweeden. Lettera della Regina di Suezia alla Republica di Genova. Indated. 1 page. Copy of a letter by Christina requesting a place on the coast of Genoa where she might settle after having left France because of the plague. With: ___________. Risposta della Republica di Genova alla Madama. Undated. 1 page. Copy of the reply granting the Queen's request.

Mazzarino, Guilio. Risposta d'una Lettera scritta al Cardinal Mazzarino concernente l'interesse di stato. 2 leaves, numbered ff. 167-168. Copy of Mazarin's reply, dated Paris, December 14, 1657, which gives an interesting analysis of international relations at a crucial point of history. It is addressed to an unidentified person in Rome. The background of the letter is England's treaty with France, signed October 23, 1657, Mazarin's alliance against Spain, the destruction of the Spanish fleet at Santa Cruz on August 7, 1657, and the surrender of Mardyk to the English on September 25.
Alexander VII, Pope. -Creatio nonnullorum Cardinalem Facta...Papam Alexandrum Septimum. 3 pages in Latin. Announcements of the appointment of a number of Cardinals by Pope Alexander VII.

Mazzarino, Giulio. Copia di Lettera scritta dal Sig. Cardinal Mazzarino al Sig. Cardinal Antonio. 4 pages, numbered 169 v.-171 r. Mazarin's letter, dated November 12, 1659, at St. Jean de Luz, contains news of the conclusion of a peace treaty between France and Spain. He requests this news to be passed on to the Pope before the official announcement which is to follow.

Alexander VII, Pope. Breve della Santita di...Papa Alessandro VII alla Republica di Lucca. 3 pages. In Latin. The papal letter, dated February 14, 1660, requests the re-admission of the Jesuits. With: Lucca, Republic of. Risposta della Republica di Lucca. 1-1/2 pages. Undated. Reply to the above letter of Pope Alexander VII assuring him that the question of re-admission of the Jesuits would be remembered.

(Christina, Queen of Sweeden). Ragvaglio del viaggio della Regina di Suezia da Copenhagen...a Sthocolm. 5 leaves, numbered 173-177. Account of the Queen's voyage from Copenhagen to Stockholm, addressed to Cardinal Azzolino and dated October 16, 1660, by an anonymous person.

(Christina, Queen of Sweeden). Altro ragvaglio dell'entrata della madama Regina di Suezia in Sthocolm. 5 pages. Another account of the Queen's entry into Stockholm, again addressed to Cardinal Azzolini by an anonymous person, and dated also October 16, 1660. Detailed description of the ceremonies held in honor of Christina, and of a diet, held at the same time which had attracted representatives from all over the world.

Alexander VII, Pope. Breve...Alexandri Papae Septimi...pro nonnullis contrversiis Romae...anno 1660. 10 leaves, numbered 179-187. In Latin. Instructions by the Pope concerning the prevention and legal settlement of violent actions which had occured in Rome.

Mazzarini, Giulio. Lettera scritta dal Cardinal Mazzarino al Cardinale Colonna in occazione del parentado contratto. 4 pages. Copy of a letter, sent from the Bois de Vincennes and dated February 23, 1661, announcing the marriage of Mazarin's niece Maria Mancini to Prince Colonna, the connestabile of Naples. Maria Mancini is known in history for attracting the passion of Louis XIV to such a degree that the king wanted to marry her. Mazarin speaks of "particular goodness" with which the monarch consented to the marriage, quoting his words as follows: "It is very just that since Cardinal Mazarin has so successfully married the Infanta, Our daughter, we should try to give him every satisfaction in regard to the marriage of his niece."

Mazzarino, Giulio. Congratulationis Epistola Alexandro VII. Pont. maximo transmissa, per ademptionem Pontificatus. 3 pages. In Latin. Copy of a letter congratulating Alexander VII upon his election to the papacy. Undated.
Philip IV, King of Spain. Lettera di S. Mta. Cattca. a S. Sta. 1 page. Copy of a letter to Pope Alexander VII, dated November 28, 1657, and announcing the birth of a son.

Leopold I of Hapsburg. Lettera scritta dall' Imperatore a sua Sta. 1 page. In Latin. Copy of a letter to Pope Alexander VII, dated July 18, 1658, and announcing Leopold's ascension to the Hapsburg throne on that day.
(Alexander VII, Pope). Inscritte. sa. alcune medaglie di Papa Alessandro VII. 2 pages. In Latin. Inscriptions on medals in honor of Pope Alexander VII.

Mazzarino, Giulio. Lettera scritta dal Cardinal Mazzarino a Sua Sta. quando era a letto mortale. infermo. 2 pages. Copy of a letter to Pope Alexander VII, dated Bois de Vincennes, March 6, 1661, when Mazarin was dangerously ill.

Louis XIV, King of France. Lettera scritta dal Re chrmo. al Re di Spagna doppo La Morte del Card. Mazzarino. 2 pages. Copy of a letter to Philip IV of Spain, dated March 9, 1661, and informing him of Mazarin's death on that day.

Louis XIV, King of France. Copia di Lettera scritta da Luiggi XIIII a Madama Marinozzi. Dated at Paris March 17, 1661, expressing the King's sympathy upon the occasion of the death of Mazarin, her brother.
Ceri, Duchess of. Lettera scritta dalla Duchessa di Ceri alla Principessa Sua Madre. 2 pages. Copy of a letter dated February 14, 1667.
Litterae ex Ungaria. 1 page. In Latin. Copy of a letter from Hungary, dated October 10, 1663, describing the political situation in Europe with a noticeable anti-French bias.

Mazzarino, Giulio. Copia di lettera scritta dal Cardinale Mazzarino alla Regina di Suezia in occasione della Pace. 1-1/2 pages. Copy of a letter to Christina of Sweeden, dated at St. Jean de Luz, Nov. 8, 1659, on the occasion of a peace treaty concluded between France and Spain.

Christina, Queen of Sweeden. Manifesto della Regina di Suezia Contro Don Antonio della Quena et altri... 10 leaves, numbered 202-211 (misnumbered 111). Undated. Copy of a statement, made by the Queen of Sweeden, against the Spanish nobleman Antonio della Quena and some others who molested her during her trip to Rome.
MISCELLANY

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: pages. 4to. Contemporary limp vellum. Italy, middle of the 17th century.

did.unittitle: Perche il barbaro ardir s'affreni... 25 pages, numbered in pencil ff. 3-16. Lyric epic poem in 49 octave stanzas on Roman conquests and their beneficial influence on the barbaric peoples.

Libro De Recollete de Vita de Filosofi, et de Ottimi esempii, e De Sententie Historie, e Favole Utilissime al viver humano. 35-1/2 pages, numbered in pencil ff. 18-35. A collection of sentences, fables, and examples of a gnomic character, including the lives and moral views of the philosophers: Aristotle, Socrates, Democritos, and Diogenes.
La Stufa. 4 leaves. Italian jocular poem in tercets ("capitolo") on hot baths.
Ohime chi non gridasse ad alta voce...-O Dio chi non gridasse ad alta voce... 5 leaves and 5 leaves. Two drafts, with corrections, of a satirical poem in tercets.
Leandro et Ero. Idilio. 8-1/2 leaves. Italian idyllic poem on the theme of Hero and Leander.
Dentici, Nicolo. Per il Duca di Nocera. 5 leaves. An epic poem in 20 octave stanzas by Nicolo Dentici.
Discorso Accademico. 4-1/2 leaves. An Italian discourse about the cruel treatment of animals by men and about the question of which is the nobler pursuit: hunting or fishing.

Rota, Bernardino. Oratio habita ad Serenos Academicos die quo Principatum deposuit, cui successit Tiberius Bucca. Title and 19 unnumbered pages. Latin speech by Bernardino Rota (1508-1575), one of the Petrarchist poets of the Cinquecento, when he ceded the presidency of the Accademia dei Sireni in Naples to his successor Tiberius Bucca.
Destra Amata mia... 1 page. A licentious Italian sonnet.
Demonstratio dari ne posse infinitu circulum. Title and 4 unnumbered pages. Latin treatise on the possibility of an infinite circle.

Calcese, Andrea. (pseudonym for?). Signore mio... 2 leaves, folio, folded to 4to and 2 pages 4to. A humorous letter in Neapolitan dialect; also a few quickly written lines and a sketch in another handwriting, and the draft of the answer in Neapolitan dialect.

Barberini. -Breve lamento del Cardinal'Antonio Barberino. -Riposta. 3 leaves. Poem of 4 line stanzas, being a short lament of Cardinal Antonio Barberini (1607-1671); also a satirical sonnet in answer to the Lamento .

(Commedia). Acts II-V. 73 leaves. Unidentified Italian comedy in prose. On the front wrapper is the word molto (part of the title?) and the date: 13 November 1624. Act I and the beginning of Act II, Scene 1 are missing.

Modo di estraere le radice quadrate per la geometria et per le ordinaze degli Bataglieri delle Fantasie in forma gadra et altre ocoretie. 9 leaves. An Italian treatise on extracting cubic roots for geometrical purposes and troup orders, with examples.
MISCELLANY

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: (misnumbered) with 28 manuscript pieces and 6 printed pamphlets. Index. 8vo. Contemporary vellum. Italy, late 17th, early 18th century.

did.unittitle: Introduzione; La Nobilita; La Liberalita. Discourses on Nobility and Liberality. 8-1/2 pages, numbered ff. 1-5.
L'Oro. Discourse on Gold. 2 pages, numbered ff. 8-9.
La Forza. Discourse on Force. 2 pages, numbered f. 10.
L'Armi; La Prudenza; La Dignità; La Bellezza. Discourses on Arms, Prudence, Dignity, Beauty. pages, numbered ff. 11-18.
Il Prencipe in decisione del questo Proposte. Decision of the President of the Academy on the question as to the priority of arms over letters, and a Madrigal. 2-1/2 pages, numbered ff. 19-20.
Statuta & Regulae...Sub invocatione Sanctae Mariae... Bylaws and regulations of the secular clerics of Holy Mary, established in Naples. In Latin. 38-1/2 pages, numbered ff. 22-41.
In Sacro Dialogo & Il Trionfo di Maria Assunta. Sacred poems. 25 pages, numbered ff. 43-61, with some blanks.

Canzoni per musica nella publica ragunanza dei Signori Accademici Occulti. Texts of 4 cantatas sung in Treviso in 1696, at the public meeting of the occulti , where the funeral rites for the King of Poland, John Sobieski (1624-1669), were held. The cantatas celebrate the greatest military victory of the king, the liberation of Vienna from the Turks (Sept. 12, 1683). Printed pamphlet. 6 leaves, numbered ff. 65-70. Treviso, 1696.

Lenzi, Gasparo Mariano. Il Viaggio alla Religione. A poem in tercets, celebrating the "monacazione" (taking the veil) of Rosalia Orsola Gennari. Printed pamphlet. 12 pages, numbered ff. 71-76. Bologna, 1704.

Posterla, Fransico. Salomon. Drama Sacrum, Latin text which was set to music by Pier Paolo Bencini, a Roman composer, and sung in the Chapel of the Confraternity of the Holy Crucifix in 1704. Printed pamphlet. 8 leaves numbered ff. 77-84 (printed pagination: 1-16).
Carmen Deo Nostro. 6 Latin poems to God, by an unknown Carmelite. Printed leaflet. 2 leaves, numbered ff. 85-86.
2 Sonetti and other poems of a satirical nature against the Papacy, the Cardinals, etc. 13-1/2 pages, numbered ff. 87-93.
Il Duca di Baviera cosi parla. A sonnet, in which the Duke of Bavaria gives a satirical picture of himself. 1 page (f. 94).
A.B.D. aflitta per la morte d'un Capuchino suo cano. Sonnet. A sententious sonnet to a lady, afflicted by the death of her lapdog. 1 page (f. 95).
Mantica, Felice Giacinto. Epigramma. A Latin epigram by F.G.M. to the Reverend Father D'Asti. 1 page (f. 96).
A Poem to the nuns of the Convent to whom Suora Celleraria brought some food. 2 pages (f. 97).
Reflessioni; Nell'Apunzione della Vergine; Sonetto, and other poems on various subjects (the earthquakes of Rimini and Fano, the Assumption of the Virgin, etc.). 5 pages, numbered ff. 102-106.
A Poem by a disappointed music lover to a friend who asked him about the doings of a troop of theatrical singers. 2-1/2 pages, numbered ff. 107-108.
2 Sonnets for the taking of the veil of Vittoria Mantica and Amaranta degli Oddi. 2 pages, numbered f. 109.

Michael Primus Paradisi. Two Latin epigrams, one against Michele Primo Paradisi; the other, expressing thanks to a Ruler for restoring peace. On verso: a sonnet to a member of an Academy. 2 pages, numbered f. 110.
2 Madrigals : per i fiori; per il ringraziamento. 1 page (f. 111).
A Sonnet to a Lady called Columba; on verso a letter, dated 8 December '96. 2 pages, numbered f. 112.

Dichiaratione... A description of the festive decorations organized in the College of the Jesuit Fathers in Naples in honor of the Archbishop Caracciolo. Printed pamphlet. 6 leaves (last one blank), numbered ff. 113-117.

Il Sentier della Gloria. An account of the Accademia di Esercizi cavallereschi (a show of chivalric exercises) held in Siena at the end of 1708, by members of the Collegio Tolomei. Printed pamphlet. 14 pages with one blank leaf, numbered ff. 119-125.

Manolessi, Evangelista. La Porchetta. Feta annua Popolare...di Luglio, & Agosto 1074 (sic: 1704). An account of the annual public fair and festive events, including the erection of a special theater, in Bologna. With a large folding plate, an etching by Carl Anton Bufagnotti after Lodovico Parti (both known for their decoration for the theater), showing the newly built open-air theater during a performance by acrobats, rope-dancers, etc. Printed pamphlet. 4 leaves, numbered ff. 127-130. Bologna, nella Impressoria Arciuescovale, 1704.
2 Letters, one by the Spanish Ambassador to the Diet of Bada, the other by the French Ambassador to the same Diet. 4 pages, unnumbered ff. 132-133.
Capitoli proposti dal Redi Francia per la conclusione della Pace. Propositions to the King of France for the conclusion of the Peace (of Ryswick, Sept. 20, 1697). 2-1/2 pages, numbered ff. 136-137.
Copia di Lettera da...Nuntio al Sig. Conte Casati... Maggio 22, 1697. Copy of a letter by the Papal Nuncio Casati, May 22, 1697. 1 page (f. 138).

Copia di Lettera...dalla Segr. di Stato al Mons... Nunzio di Lucerna...Dic. 13, 1697. Copy of a letter written by the Secretary of State to the Nuncio of Luzern concerning the election of the Bishop of Coira. 1-1/2 pages (f. 139).

Lettera della Republica di Venetia al Rè Christianissima...nella nascita del Duca di Bretagna. A letter written by the Republic of Venice to the King of France, congratulating him on the birth of the Duke of Brittany. 1-1/2 pages (f. 140).
Grievances of a Cardinal regarding questions of etiquette, titles, and a reply to the grievances. 4-1/2 pages, numbered ff. 142-144.

Manifeste du Duc Moles, Ambassadeur du feu Charles II, Roy d'Espagne...à la Cour Imperiale. (Vienna) Dated March 19, 1703. Printed pamphlet. 8 leaves (last blank), numbered ff. 183-189. Moles protests against the seizure of his property ordered by the Government of Spain after the death of Charles II, to whom Moles was Ambassador. Moles was compelled to "embrace the sacred anchor of protection" of Emperor Leopold of Austria, who had given him shelter.

Letters dated July 22, 1701, signed by Henri de Lorraine and Marechal de Catinat, protesting against the invasion of Mantuan territory by the troops of the Austrian Emperor. Plus a letter by the Elector of Cologne to the Electors of Mainz, Trier, and Bavaria, suggesting that the Duke of Mantua may not be guilty of having admitted foreign troops into his territory and of having been in collusion with foreign powers. The Austrian invasion of Mantua was based on this charge. 3-1/2 pages, numbered ff. 191-192.
Two private letters. dealing with family matters. 3 pages, numbered ff. 193-194.
MISCELLANY
did.physdesc: 143 ms. poems, a few letters, plays, and a decree,

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: comprising 296 leaves. In Italian, with some in Latin. 4to. Contemporary vellum. Italy, late 17th century.

did.unittitle: Una certa Marchesa. Sonnet. 1 page (f. 1).
Con fato Amici... Sonnet. 1 page (f. 3).
Che in tempo d'Inn. XI... Sonnet. 1 page (f. 4).
Dà questi Cardinali irresoluti. Poem. 1 page (f. 5).
Roma Supplicante. Sonnet. 1 page (f. 6).
Il gioco dell'Oca. Poem. 2 pages, numbered f. 7r-7v.
Pontificato di Garaffa. Sonnet on Pope Paul IV. 1 page (f. 8).
Ogni cosa buona vien dal Cielo. Sonnet. 1 page (f. 11v).
Sonetto al serenis'Duca di Lorena. Sonnet. 1 page (f. 12).
Al medemo (medesimo). Sonnet. 1 page (f. 12v).
Sop. l'immacolata Concezione... Sonnet. 1 page (f. 13).
Sopra un Cavaliere che desiderando d'aver amista con una dama... Sonnet. 1 page (f. 13v).
L'Allude al Med'. Sonnet. 1 page (f. 14).
Per la temperata salute del gran Monarca Luigi il Grande. (Louis XIV). Sonnet. 1 page (f. 14v).
Al Med'. Sonnet. 1 page (f. 15).
L'Allude ad una Fontana dell'M.P. d'Aste. Sonnet. 1 page (f. 15v).
Un Padre be avvisato della morte d'un suo figlio. Sonnet. 1 page (f. 16).
Al medemo. Sonnet. 1 page (f. 16v).
I propositi di Monsig. Bottini. A play, one act, in verses. 12-1/2 pages, numbered ff. 17-23.
L'Addolorata Roma ritrovandosi Vedova per la Morte di Clemante Nono (Pope from 1667-1669) cerca tre Cardinali per novo Marito. Poem. 14-1/2 pages, numbered ff. 27-34.
A begl'Occi di Dama. Sonnet. 1 page (f. 35).
Ad un bel Capo di Dama acconcio. Sonnet. 1 page (f. 35v).
Ad una Fontana dell'Ill. S. d'Aste. Sonnet. 1 page (f. 36).
Per la Partonza d'Olimpia da Roma. Sonnet. 1 page (f. 35v).
Roma Supplicante. Sonnet. 3 pages, numbered ff. 38-39.
Ad Olimpia rappresentante in Roma 1692. Sonnet. 1 page (f. 40).
Alla Med. per la Partenza. Sonnet. 1 page (f. 40).
Muore il Pastor supremo... Sonnet. 2 pages, numbered 41 r and v.
Il Padre accertato della Morte d'un figlio. Sonnet. 1 page (f. 42).
Al M.S.P. il P. Fra Lorenzo di S. Maria Pred. in Giesu e Maria di Roma 1692. Sonnet. 1 page (f. 43v).
Dante De Purgatorio nel Canto VI, Canto VII. 3 lines from Dante's Purgatorio, Canto VI, and 6 lines from Canto VIII. 1/2 page (f. 44).
Al Leonardo Rosa. Sonnet. 1 page (f. 44v).
Un Occ. d'esser stato figorato in Inghilterra il Rè di Francia con la Conoccia. Sonnet. 1 page (f. 45).
Al Gran Monarca Luiggi il Grande per la Recuperata Sanità. Sonnet about Louis XIV. 1 page (f. 45v).
All'Ill. Prencipe Medina Celi...Del Gran Monarca Cattolico--Alla Santita d'Innoc. XI per l'ingresso dovea fare in Roma. Sonnet. 1 page (f. 46v).
A begl'occhi di Dama. Sonnet, repetition of no. 22. 1 page (f. 47).
Ad un bel Capo di Dama acconcio. Sonnet (see no. 23). 1 page (f. 47v).
Ad un Fontana... Sonnet (see no. 24). 1 page (f. 48).
Per la Partenza d'Olimpia da Roma. Sonnet (see no. 25). 1 page (f. 48v).
Al Destino. Sonnet. 1 page (f. 49).
Al M. Rvdo. Padre Fran. Maria Giunti Predicatore in S. Marcello di Roma. L'anno MDCXCII. Sonnet. 1 page (f. 49v).
A L'Olimpia rappresentante in Roma 1692. Sonnet. 1 page (f. 50).
Al Gran Monarca Luiggi il Grande. Per le presa di Namur. Sonnet. 1 page (f. 50v).
Cadde l'Anglia... Sonnet. 1 page (f. 51).
A un bel Capo ben acconcio de Dama. Sonnet (see nos. 23, 38). 1 page (f. 52).
Per la temperata salute del Gran Monarca Luiggi il Grande. Poem (see no. 15). 2 pages, numbered f. 53r and v.
Sonetto del Marino. 1/2 page (f. 56).
Dante sopra il Limbo. 1 page (f. 56v).
Sopra Fortuna e dorme. Sonnet. 1 page (f. 57).
A Begl'Occhi di Dama. Sonnet (see nos. 22 & 37). 1 page (f. 57v).
Preghiera al Cristianis. Rè Luiggi il Grande. Sonnet. 1 page (f. 58).
Cadde l'Anglia. Sonnet (see no. 45). 1 page (f. 58v).
Ord. dato dal Vescovo di Granoble a Tutti Curati della sua Diocese. Order by the Bishop of Grenoble (?) to his curates. 1/2 page (f. 59).
Ad un bel Capo di Dama... Sonnet (see nos. 23, 38, & 46). 1 page (f. 59v).
Per la temperata dell'Ill. S. Bened. d'Asti. Sonnet. 2 pages, numbered f. 60r and v.
Del Natale del Gran Monarco Cattolico Carlo II Celebrato a 6 November 1687. Sonnet to the birth of Charles II, King of Spain. 1 page (f. 61).
Per l'espugnazione della Rovella. Sonnet. 1 page (f. 61v).
Nell'Ingresso dell'...Principe Medina Celi...del Gran Monarca Cattolico Carlo II Alla Stà. d'Innocenzio XI. Sonnet. 1 page (f. 62).
Difetti della devotis. Imagine del Pianto. Ode. 1-1/2 pages, numbered ff. 62v-63r.
L'Allude ad una Fontana d'Acque. Sonnet (see no. 17). 1 page (f. 63v).
Al Fato. Sonnet. 1 page (f. 64).
Al Medemo. Sonnet. 1 page (f. 64v).

Lettera venuta da Napoli...con il Procaccia delli 5.Agosto 1636 con la quale si consiglia Roma sua Sorella sopra li Trattati del Suo matrimonio A Sorama Carnale... Sonnet. 11 pages, numbered ff. 67-73.
Risposta data da Roma alla proposta venuta da Napoli... Sonnet. 8 pages, numbered ff. 74-77v.
Consiglio al S. Card. Chigi. (Flavio Chigi, Cardinal 1657). Satirical poem with the refrain: "Flavio Chigi sta'in Cervello." 8-1/2 pages, numbered ff. 78-82.
A'Innocenzo XI. (Pope, d. 1676). Sonnet. 1 page (f. 82v).
Fischiate dei Trasteverini. Sonnet. 4-1/2 pages, numbered ff. 83-85.
Monsig. Santi Pilastri. Poem. 1 page (f. 86).
Cibascitu, Dè ratia, issu fracassu... Sonnet. 1 page (f. 87).
Ottave Morali. Octave stanzas. 2 pages, numbered f. 88r & v.
La Musa in Conclave. Terzet. 9 pages, numbered ff. 89-93.
Alla Santa mem: d'Innocenzo XI in tempo d'Alessandro VIII. Sonnet. (Alexander VIII, Pope 1689-1691). 1 page (f. 98).
Vaneggiamente del Card. Ottobono in morte d'Alessandro VI. Poem. 3-1/2 pages, numbered ff. 99-100v.
Al Cardinal Panfilio. Sonnet. 1 page (f. 101).
Sogno della S. Contessa Carpegna. Sonnet. 1 page (f. 101v).
La Giostra. Poem with refrain: "Quanti fami dello Stordito." 7 pages, numbered ff. 103-106r.
Rifesa delle Dame Romane... Poem. 6 pages, numbered ff. 106v-109r.
Sotto Toga un Moscon soura gran Corte... Sonnet, 1 page (f. 109v).
Lamento di Roma. Sonnet, 1 page (f. 110r).
Epitaphium...Alexander VIII Pontifex optim. Max... Anno LXXXII. In Latin. 1-1/2 pages, numbered ff. 110v-111r.
Risposta alla Composizione Initolata Le Muse al Sagro Collegio. Poem. 4-1/2 pages, numbered ff. 111-113v.
Pasquino e... Ottave Stanzas. 9-1/2 pages, numbered ff. 115-119v.
Hieri alla Roba essendomi portato... Poem. 8-1/2 pages, numbered ff. 121-125r.
Poiche Pietro Ottobono il Veneziano... Terzet. 11-1/2 pages, numbered ff. 125-130v.
Risposta di Pasquino à Marforio. 5-1/2 pages, numbered ff. 131-133v.
Il Cardinal Ottobono Penitenta Canzona. 3-1/2 pages, numbered ff. 139-140v.
Contro i Satirici di Roma. Sonnet. 1 page (f. 141).
Pasquino Medico. Sonnet. 1 page (f. 141v).
Al Sig. Cardinal Lorenzo Altieri per il fuoco che abbugiò la sua Credenza in Conclave. Sonnet. 1 page (f. 142r).
Sopra il Foco del Conclave. Sonnet. 1 page (f. 142v).
Il Botteghino. Poem with the refrain: "E finito il Botteghino." 2-1/2 pages, numbered ff. 143-144.
Gondole interrogate dal Bucenzoro. Poem with the refrain: "Confessaze al Buzzentoro." 18 pages, numbered ff. 145-153v.
La Scravaganze di Don. Tarquinia, et il Matrimonio stabilito tra essa e Don Marco Ottoboni. Poem. 7-1/2 pages, numbered ff. 154-157v.
Il Campanaccio. Poem with the refrain: "E sonato il Campanaccio." 3 pages, numbered ff. 158-159.
Risposta alla Satira contro le Satire. Poem. 5-1/2 pages, numbered ff. 160-162v.
Il Colascione à tre corde. Poem. 18-1/2 pages, numbered ff. 164-173.
Il Forestiero. Poem. 19 pages, numbered ff. 174-183.
Pasquino Corazzo dismesso chiede l'elemosina. Poem. 4 pages, numbered ff. 184-185.
Roma Assassinata. Poem. 15-1/2 pages, numbered ff. 186-193v.
Papa Alessandro Ottavo nella sua malatia più volte moribondo. Sonnet. 1 page (f. 194).
Memoriale della Puttane à Pasquino per l'occasione della Nembrini messa... Madrigal. 1 page (f. 195r).
Nascita dell'Abb. Tassi. Sonnet. 1 page (f. 195v).
Al Cardinal Rubini. Sonnet. 1 page (f. 196r).
Epitaphium...Hic iacet Alexander octavus... and Distichon. In Latin. 1 page (f. 197r).
Memoriale della Suttane Nobili, starting "Magnifico Pasquino..." Poem in several parts. 2-1/2 pages, numbered ff. 198-199.
Cosa ni fè Papa Alessandro mai... Sonnet. 1-1/2 pages, numbered ff. 199r & v.
Musa da Cetra illanguidita... Poem. 6 pages, numbered ff. 200-202v.
La Lagrime di B. Antonio Ottoboni. Poem. 7 pages, numbered ff. 204-207.

Sette Ostacoli, che si trovano in ciascheduno de presensori del Papato. Poem. 9-1/2 pages, numbered ff. 208-212v. This represents a roster of various candidates to the Papacy (Cibo, Altieri, Barbarigo, Spinola, Conti, Carpegna), and below the name of each are the personal draw-backs militating against their election.
Papa Alessandro 8. Sonnet. 1 page (f. 213r).
All'Abb. Tassi. Sonnet. 1 page (f. 213v).
Gran Papa ò Pantaloni... Sonnet. 1 page (f. 214).
Ventiquattro son sonate... Canzone, with the refrain: "Ventiquattro son Sonate." 2-1/2 pages, numbered ff. 218-219.
Sfogo Poetico ne Praesenti tempi. Poem. 2-1/2 pages, numbered ff. 220-221.
Risposta all'Aria ne conosco qualche d'una. Poem. 2-1/2 pages, numbered ff. 222-223v.
Si allude all'opera de Colombo. Sonnet. 1 page (f. 224).
Confessione dell'Abb. Tassi avanti al Papa. Sonnet. 1 page (f. 224v).
Difesa della Dame di Roma contra il Pri'pe D. Antonio Ottobono. and Buon Viaggio, che dà La Nembrini à D. Ant.. and Al S. Abb. Tatti. Sonnets. 2 pages, numbered ff. 225r & v.
L'Anime scordate al Card. Ottoboni. Sonnet. 1 page (f. 226).
L'Invenzione. Sonnet. 1 page (f. 226v).
Stato di Roma nel Pontificato di Alessandro VIII. Sonnet and a list of cardinals with their respective characteristics. 3 pages, numbered ff. 228-229.
Al Sepolcro di Alessandro Ottavo. Miracoli d'esso. Poem, and A D. Antonio. Sonnet. 1-1/2 pages, numbered ff. 229v-230.
Vita, Morte, e Miracoli di Alessandro Ottavo. Poem. 15-1/2 pages, numbered ff. 232-239v.
Canzonette morali. 13 pages, numbered ff. 240-246.
Canto. Con cui si descrive il correggio che hebbe La Bara di Papa Alessandro Ottavio dal Quirinale al Vaticano. 5-1/2 pages, numbered ff. 248-250v.
La Corte di Cardinal Ottoboni. Poem. 4 pages, numbered ff. 252-253v.
Risposta al Sonetto di Fabretti. Madrigale. 1/2 page (f. 254).
Relazione fatta dalli SSi. Leonini nella Causa del Bordello. Poem. 1 page (f. 256).
Decisione di Pasquino. Poem. 1 page (f. 256v).
Per L'Abbate Tassi. Sonnet. 1 page (f. 257).
Il Colombo, a Crazeo Pradelini per haverlo strappazato nella sua opera. Sonnet. 1 page (f. 257v).
Satiro in Lode di Aless. 8. e Suoi Nipoti. Poem. 5-1/2 pages, numbered ff. 258-260v.
Per consiglio à Cardinali Imperiali, e Spagnoli. Poem. 14 pages, numbered ff. 263-269v.
Febo Vaticinanze, e non maledico. Poem. 5-1/2 pages, numbered ff. 271-273v.
L'Abbate Tassi che si difende per esser stato chiamato Roffiando. Poem. 2-1/2 pages, numbered ff. 275-276.
Per Barbigero Papa. 1 page (f. 277).
E ben passo chi pretende... Poem. 1-1/2 pages, numbered ff. 279v-280.

Fiamma del Ciel... Sonnet. 3-1/2 pages, numbered ff. 281-282v. These are, without mention by the author, anti-clerical sonnets by Petrarch (from the Canzionere) which express Petrarch's indignation against the Papal Court of Avignon.
In Alexandri VII a Christina Regiae Suecia Regina... Poem. In Latin. 1 page (f. 285).
De Tres Coronas. Poem. 1 page (f. 285v).
La Chitarra del Marino. Poem. Title page and 9-1/2 pages, numbered ff. 287-292v.
Copy of a Decree of Louis XIV, dated Versailles, July 22, 1688. 2 pages, numbered ff. 295v-296.
BOVIO, CARLO, S.J. VARIAE COMPOSITIONES, & ARGUMENTA

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Ms. in Italian and Latin. 142 numbered Leaves. 8vo. Contemporary vellum. Rome, 1648.

did.unittitle: Bovio, Carlo, S. J.> Variae Compositiones, & Argumenta. A collection of short compositions in Italian and Latin prose. Bovio (1614-1705), a Jesuit Father, mirrors in his writings the devotional and sermonizing activities of his Order, and the ornate and the aureate style of the Seicento. This volume contains a great variety of topics, many on religious subjects or historical events, oratorical speeches, etc. From leaf 95-106, there are some Monica , i.e. instructions, which concern the policy of the Jesuit Order towards a ruler or a nobleman, confession, or sermons, or other important matters of this kind. From leaf 107 to the end, there are rules for meditation and prayer. Not in De Backer-Sommervogel.
MISCELLANY

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: A collection of 30 manuscript treatises, speeches, and poems in Latin, a few in Italian. 144 leaves, including some blanks. 8vo. Contemporary vellum. Italy, probably second half of the 17th century.

did.unittitle: De Academia Ruri instituendae. A speech (with a splendid description of Capodimonte, Naples, Vesuvius) concerning an Academy to be established in the countryside. 24-1/2 pages, numbered dd. 1-13.
Laus Calami Scriptorii. A speech in praise of the pen. 6 pages, numbered ff. 14-16.
De Natalis Christi reparatoris nocte. On the Natal night (i.e. Christmas) of Christ the Redeemer. Speech. 14-1/2 pages, numbered ff. 16-23.
De Christi Liberatoris Anastasi. On the Resurrection of Christ. And: De Christi Redivivi Vulneribus. On the wounds of Christ reborn. Speeches. Together 4 pages, numbered ff. 24-25v.
Paradoxum Christianum. A Christian paradox. Speech. 5-1/2 pages, numbered ff. 26-28v.
De Providenzia et Religione Jungenda. On the conjunction of Providence and Religion. 4-1/2 pages, numbered ff. 29-31.
De Natali die Deipara Virginis Sanctissimae. Oratio. On the birthday of the most Holy Virgin. 9-1/2 pages, numbered ff. 31-35v.
De Eloquenzia cum Pietate Jungenda. Oratio. On the conjunction of eloquence with religion. This composition contains the principles of Christian Humanism. 10 pages, numbered ff. 36-40v.
Prolusio de Imitatione. -Prolusione de Narratione. Two discourses, one on imitation, the other on narration. 4-1/2 pages, numbered ff. 41-43.
Beati Aloysii. Oratio. A speech in praise of San Luigi (Gonzaga). 16 pages, numbered ff. 44-51.
De Beato Stanislao Kostka. Oratio. An oratorical eulogy of Saint Stanislaus Kostka (d. 1568). 12-1/2 pages, numbered ff. 51-58.
In Universo Philosophia. Prolusio. Oration on the whole extent of philosophy. 2 pages, numbered ff. 58v-59r.
Elementorum Certamen... (The Battle of the Elements). An example of the fortitude shown by Saint Francis Xavier during a sea storm. 2 pages, numbered ff. 60r-60v.
Laus Musices. Latin oration in praise of Music. 2-1/2 pages, numbered ff. 61-62.
De ostentatione ignavorum. On the ostentations of cowardly people. 2 pages, numbered ff. 62-63.
Propria quoniam non pelle quiesset. 1 page, numbered ff. 63r & 63v.
De Sacro Oratore. On the sacred orator, i.e. the ecclesiastical preacher. 3-1/2 pages, numbered ff. 63v-65.
Exercitatio de Amplificatione. An exercise in rhetorical amplification. 15-1/2 pages, numbered ff. 67-75v.
De Elogio... On the rhetorical technique. 27 pages, numbered ff. 67-89.
De D. Joanne in Caenz... Poem. 1-1/2 pages, numbered ff. 95r-96v.
Huius atavis... Ode. 2 pages, numbered ff. 96r-96v.
De Sydere orto. Poem. 7-1/2 pages, numbered ff. 97-100v.
Tergemini Soles. Poem. 5 pages, numbered ff. 101-102v.
Sub Variis Allegoria. Poem. 4 pages, numbered ff. 103-104.
De Anagrammate. On anagrams and their rhetorical rules. 10 pages, numbered ff. 105-109.
Ita definit epicenius. On the epicenium, the epitaph, the pervigilium as literary genres and the rules governing the metres of Latin lyrical poetry. 27 pages, numbered ff. 110-123.
De emblemate. On emblems. Rhetorical figures (emblemata, schemata, etc.). 11-1/2 pages, numbered 125-130v.
Hebrea Mater Galesi... Epistola. An epistle in Latin distichs in which a Hebrew mother relates the death of her child during the Slaughter of the Innocents. 3 pages, numbered ff. 131-132.
Two Latin Poems. The first concerns San Luigi (Gonzaga); the second, Saint Ignatius of Loyola. 20 pages, numbered ff. 132v-143.
NOTEBOOK

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: A manuscript notebook in Latin, comprising 984 pages, numbered ff. 1-603. Possibly the note book of Giulio Riccio, pupil of Angelo Gallucci (1593-1674), professor of Rhetoric at the Jesuit College in Rome. Entry dates given are 1631 and 1637. Thick 8vo. Contemporary vellum. Rome, c. 1630-1640.

did.unittitle: Eloquencia Salutaris. -Divinitatis laudavio. etc. Panegyrics on miscellaneous topics, from moral qualities to animals. Ms. in Latin. These panegyrics are made up of notes taken down by a student named Giulio Riccio (verso leaf 96), in the class room of his teacher Angelo Gallucio (professor of Rhetorics). The date is given as 1637. 188 pages, numbered ff. 4-96.

Theologia Flores cum Aliis quamplurimis Titulis. Theological topics like God, Christ, the Virgin, etc., in alphabetical order. Under each title, a set of descriptive phrases concerning the respective topic. 248 pages (many filled only partly), numbered ff. 119-242.
Rose descripcio. Description of the Rose. 4-1/2 pages, numbered ff. 243-245.
Sanctissimus ille Doctrina Mystagogus... A mystical treatise, author not specified, which seems to be inspired by a medieval mystic, probably St. Bonaventure. 108 pages, numbered ff. 266-319.
De Passione Domini. -Oratio. by Francesco Piccolomini. 5-1/2 pages, numbered ff. 320-322v.
De Passione Domini. -Oratio. by Stefano Zucchi, a Jesuit. 3 pages, numbered ff. 324-325.
De Passione Domini. -Oratio. by Baldassarre Cittadella. 6 pages, numbered ff. 326-328v.
De Passione Domine. -Oratio. by Leone Santi. 5 pages, numbered ff. 330-332.
E'multis elegantibus lineamentis... A treatise based on the analogy between various type of angels and the representatives of the ecclesiastical hierarchy. 34 pages, numbered ff. 334-350v.
Rettorica Biblioteca. Lecture notes from a class in rhetoric. 6-1/2 pages, numbered ff. 353-356 and 25-1/2 pages, numbered ff. 361-373.
Tractatus de Epistolis. A small treatise on letter-writing. 11-1/2 pages, numbered ff. 375-380v.
Annotationes ex Oratione D. Tarquinii de innocentiae cede. On the Slaughter of the Innocents. 5 pages, numbered ff. 381-383v.
Orationis XXIV De Beato Aloizio Gonzaga. Selecte annotationes. Annotation on a panegyric eulogizing a Jesuit saint. 4-1/2 pages, numbered ff. 384-386.
Gemmarum Alphabetum. A collection of phrases describing gems, in alphabetical order, starting with Agathe. Also, flowers, giants, heros, etc. 11 pages, numbered ff. 389-394.

Formularium Liber. A collection of oratorical description: of a battle, actions in war, the panegyric of an unconquered general, and a description of a football match, etc. 4-1/2 pages, numbered ff. 395-410.
Oratiuncula... A short speech on the different activities of man. 3 pages, numbered ff. 411-412.
Blessi Aloisii Gonzaga. An oration in praise of St. Luigi Gonzaga, presumably delivered by Giulio Riccio, in 1631, in a class of the Collegio Romano. 6-1/2 pages, numbered ff. 413-416.
Virgo sine labe concepta... A speech in praise of the Immaculate Virgin Mary. 6 pages, numbered ff. 421-423v.
Franciscus Xaverius...Oratio. A panegyric on St. Francis Xavier. 4 pages, numbered ff. 425-426v.
De Lacrimis. Treatises and various poems on the mystical significance of tears. 163 pages, numbered ff. 429-520. Contains also a panegyric treatise by Franciscus Brivius (see no. 22).
Varia Genera Carminum. Various kinds of poems. 194 pages, numbered ff. 521-581v (some blank).

Brivius, Franciscus. De Diva Catharina Panegiricus. Brivius (1597-1666) became a member of the Jesuit Order in 1614 and later professor of rhetoric at the Collegio Romano. A panegyric on Diva Catharina. 7-1/2 pages, numbered ff. 582-586v.
Varia Carmina. 14 poems. 27-1/2 pages, numbered ff. 588-603v.
SPINOLA, LAZARO. LIBRO...DE DIVERSE MATERIE

Spinola, Lazaro, Libro nel quale si trata de diverse materie utilissime ad agn'uno . Manuscript. Title page (some words affected by ink erosion) and 163 pages, numbered ff. 1-82. 8vo. Contemporary limp vellum. Milan, (1643).
A manuscript of contemplations on history, the pages fully covered in an easily legible 17th century hand, probably that of the author, who calls himself "abbate e priore."

unittitle.title: ORDEN, COMO SE HA DE GOVERNAR UN BUEN SOLDADO

did.unittitle: Orden, Como se ha de Governar un Buen Soldado. Manuscript in Spanish. 77-1/2 pages, numbered ff. 1-39. Contemporary vellum. (Naples, 17th century?).

A calligraphically written copy of a manual on military regulations and organization, the duties of various officers, military groups, etc. The manuscript seems to be incomplete. The anonymous author was probably a Spanish officer of the 17th century in the service of the Viceroy of Naples.
MISCELLANEOUS DOCUMENTS

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: comprising 140 pages, numbered ff. 1-79, including 1 leaf manuscript index. 4to, unless otherwise stated. Contemporary limp vellum. Italy, first quarter of the 17th century.

did.unittitle:
(Henry IV, King of France).
Dichiarazione, et Ordine del Re Contente le Cagioni dell'haver mosso Guerra al Duca di Savoia. Manifest by the King of France, justifying his taking up arms against Charles Emmanuel I, Duke of Savoy. Translated from the French. Printed Pamphlet. 4 leaves, numbered ff. 2-5. Florence, Marescotti, 1600.
Apparently very rare, not in the catalogues of the British Museum or the Bibliothèque Nationale.
Discorso della Guerra fra i Genovesi e il Duca di Savoia nell'anno 1629. Charles Emmanuel I of Savoy was defeated by the Genoese. Manuscript. 20 pages, numbered ff. 6-16v.

Descrittion Breve di Ferrara nel cui dominio sia stata et sia. An account of Ferrara's history (then belonging to the States of the Church), and the different dominations under which it has been since the time of Charlemagne. Manuscript. 22 pages, numbered ff. 20-31v.

La Restitutione di Clerac, con le parole tenute da quelli di Clerac, che hanno mandato verso il Re per rimetterli la piazza nelle sue mani ali 4 di Agosto 1621. Translated from the French. Printed pamphlet on the restitution of the Catholic religion in 1621, when Louis XIII seized the Huguenot strongholds. With a list of the cities that surrendered to the King. 4 leaves, numbered ff. 34-37. Venice, Antonio Pinelli, 1621.

Viaggio del Illmo. et Rev. Sig. Monsignor Ottavio Santa Croce Vescovo di Cervia, destinato da sua Santità per suo Nuntio alli XXIX di Marzo presso la Cesarea Maesta Rodolfo Imperatore all'hora residente per una Dieta in Praga nella Bohemia. An account of the trip of Ottavio Santa Croce, bishop of Servia and papal nuncio, to the Imperial Diet, held at Prague. Manuscript. 24 pages (the end is missing), numbered ff. 38-49v. N.pl., 1581.

Oratione, over Parlamento del Duca di Hernia, nel Conseglio di Spagna. Printed pamphlet. A speech dealing with the question of whether Spain should lay down weapons and forgive the Duke of Savoy (Charles Emmanuel I), or prosecute the war and despoil him of his territorial possessions and destroy the menace he represents to the State of Milan. 4 leaves (last blank), numbered ff. 50-52v. N.pl., n.d. (c. 1615).

Breve informatione delle differenze, che passano con Monsig. Paravicino Vescovo d'Alessandria, per servitio della sua Chiesa, nella diffesa dell' Immunita Ecclesiastica particolamente. A printed pamphlet on the diffeences concerning ecclesiastical policy between Erasmus Paravicino, Bishop of Alexandria, and Rome, including letters to and by Paravicino, dated 1623-1626. 8 leaves, numbered in pencil 54-60. N. pl., n.d. (Rome, 1626).

Relatione Della Rotta data dal Sig. di Toiras, Luogotenente di Monsù di Pernone per il Rè Christianissimo à Monsù di Subisse, capo d'Heretici Ribelli, di nuovo sollevato contro sua M. nel Paese di Modoc, nella Riviera di Bordeo. Printed pamphlet, translated from the French. An account of the defeat inflicted by M. Toiras, lieutenant of M. d'Epernon, upon M. de Soubise, leader of the rebellious "heretics." Soubise is Benjamin de Rohan, seigneur de Soubise, a leader of the Huguenots during the reign of Louis XIII. 4 leaves, numbered ff. 62-65v. Small 8vo. Paris and Rome, 1625.

Seconda Rotta dei Rebelli Heretici di Mont'Albano, data dall'Esercito del Rè Christianissimo. Printed pamphlet. Account of the second defeat inflicted upon the Huguenots by M. d'Epernon. 4 leaves, numbered ff. 66-69v. Small 8vo. Lyons, Rome. 1625.

Relatione del Negotiato Dalli Deputati di Savoia in Milano per l'accommodamento delle differenze con Mantova. Printed pamphlet. An account of the negotiations (1622) between the Dukes of Savoy and of Mantua concerning the settlement of a monetary dispute. 4 leaves, numbered ff. 70-73v.

Risposta alla Relatione stampata in Torino, Sopra el negotiato dalli Deputati di Savoia in Milano, per l'accommodamento delle differenze con Mantova. Printed pamphlet. A reply to the preceding. 12 pages, numbered ff. 74-79v. Leaf 79v contains a Relatione fatta al Signor Duca di Feria dal Sig. Conte Luigi Arconati , dated Milan, April 28, 1622. N. pl., n.d. (1622).
GIOTTINI, P. L'ASTROLOGO
Giottini, P., L'Astrologo. Commedia. 89 ff. Ms. on paper. Small 8vo. Contemporary stiff grey wrappers. N.pl., n.d.

This volume contains a comedy-play by a certain P. Giottini, L'Astrologo , which was apparently never printed. The roles of Tognello and Pulcinella are written in the Neapolitan dialect. Comic contrasts are obtained by exploiting the peculiarities of French, Florentine, German, and Neapolitan.
COMMEDIA IN PROSA
A comedy play in 5 acts of the 17th century. No title is given. 99 ff. Ms. on paper. Small 4to. Contemporary vellum. N.pl., n.d.
Commedia in Prosa. The play is written in prose. The author could not be identified.
LITERARY MISCELLANY
Parts of Boccaccio's Decamerone and other samples of literary style and rhetoricas phrases. Ms. on paper. 107 ff., including 4 blank leaves. Small 4to. Contemporary limp vellum. N. pl., n.d.

This volume contains a series of passages chosen for their stylistic elegance from Boccaccio's Decamerone, ff. 1-94. Various sonnets and canzonets in Italian, ff. 95-100. Elegant rhetorical phrases and a fragment of a poem in Italian tercets, ff. 106-107.
GILIO DA FABRIANIO. SERMO...
Gilio de Fabriano. Sermo, de sancto Jubilei anno. Ms. on paper. 3 leaves, 35 numbered pages. Small 4to. Contemporary limp vellum. N. pl., Sept. 24, 1599.
Sermon in Latin on the Holy Jubilee of 1599 by Onofrio Gilio da Fabriano.
COMEDIES IN PROSE
did.physdesc: 4 volumes. Ms. on paper. Together 259 ff. Small

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: 4to. Contemporary limp vellum.

did.unittitle: Spina, Ascanio. L'Inconstante. Ms. on paper. 73 ff. The binding is a parchment document in Latin of the 16th or 17th century. N.pl., n.d.
A comedy play in 5 acts which was acted once in Naples. Presumably this play was not printed.
Comedy in Prose. Comedy in prose. No title. Ms. on paper. 64 ff. N.pl., n.d.
On the first leaf is the following notation in pencil: "Gio. Btta Regni (Begni?) carcerato settimane in secreta il Lottis Balagi," indicating that Regni was either the author or the copyist.
Comedy in Prose. Comedy in prose in three acts. Ms. on paper. 64 leaves. N.pl., n.d.

An untitled play of the heroic-comic genre, with historical personages and stock characters from the commedia dell'arte . One of the central personages seems to be Julian the Apostate. Perhaps this play was named after him? Much pageantry, stage directions call for incidental music.
Comedy in Prose. Prose comedy in three acts. Ms. on paper. 133 pp. N.pl., n.d.

A comedy play, untitled (perhaps by Giovanni Girolamo Benetti, a Roman, whose name appears on verso of the last blank leaf). The genre of this play is a combination of the mythological with the commedia dell'arte world. Typical in this respect is the scene between Pantalone (stock character of the Commedia dell'arte) and Venus (pp. 78-79). Pantalone speaks in the Venetian dialect, Venus in correct standard Italian.
PARETUS AND RELATED AUTHORS

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Consisting of 8 volumes. 6 or more by Paretus on Philosophy and Sciences, the later ones possibly by other, anonymous authors. Ms. in Latin, on paper. 2758 pages, 18 leaves, 1 drawing of the human brain (vol. 2), and 9 folding diagrams. Small 4to. Contemporary limp vellum. Each volume has an index at the end. N.pl., n.d.

did.unittitle: Paretus. Institutionem Logicarum. Treatise on the principles of Logic. 203 pages.
Paretus. Sequel to the proceding. On the sensory faculties, operation of the mind, judgement. pp. 204-654 and index. Drawing of the human brain at beginning.

Paretus. Continuation. On fantasy, imagination; waking and sleeping state; union of soul and body; refutation of the views of Descartes and Malebranche on this topic; memory, reminiscence. pp. 655-813.

Paretus. On metaphysics, the existence of God; attributes of god; operations of God; predetermination; man's soul; immortality of the soul; main point of the Aristotelian system; de accidentibus; formae substantiales; the soul of animals; the mechanical explanation of the anima brutorum . 400 pages and 5 leaves.

Paretus. General introduction to physics: on the essence of the body; divisibility of bodies; elements of chemistry; infinite divisibility of the infinitesimals according to Newton and Leibniz; space; time; the infinite. 362 pages, 2 folding diagrams, 4 leaves index.

Paretus. On the genesis and nature of sound; on the organ of hearing; the object and sense of smell and touch; on the problem of Gravity: is it possible to construct a ship for navigation in the air? The answer is in the affirmative. Appendix I: longitude and latitude of the earth's regions; size of the earth. Appendix II: on the efficient cause of gravity; geometrical measurements. 377 pages, 9 leaves index, 2 folding diagrams, including a cross section of the human ear and a design for a flying ship.
Dissertatio de lumine , and other treatises. On Newton's theory of colors; the mechanism of vision; catoptrics; the telescope; electricity. 456 pages, 3 folding diagrams.

Dissertatio II. De impenetrabilitate. On impenetrability; inertia; second and third Newtonian law; central forces; cause of speed; universal gravity of bodies; laws of gravity; for a better understanding of Newtonian theory; phenomena of tides; Galileo's opinion refuted; Descarte's opinion refuted; Kepler's view refuted; Newton's theory approved; nature of comets. 350 pages, 8 folding diagrams.
BARONIO, CESARE. ANNALES ECCLESIASTICI

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Vol. III, IV. 2 vols. Ms. in Latin. 1170 pages, 13 unnumbered pages. Small 4to. Contemporary limp vellum. N.pl., June 1, 1629-Jan. 30, 1633.

did.unittitle: Baronio, Ceare. Annales Ecclesiastici. Vol. III. 597 pages and 4 unnumbered pages as index. N.pl., June 1, 1629-July 21, 1630.
An abridgment of the third tome of the Annales Ecclesiastici by Cardinal Cesare Baronio (1538- 1607).
Baronio, Cesare. Annales Ecclesiastici. Vol. IV. 5 unnumbered, 373, 4 unnumbered pages. N.pl., July 22, 1630-January 30, 1633.

Continuation of the preceding volume. Cardinal Baronio was confessor of Clement VIII, and later chief librarian of the Vatican Library. The Annales Ecclesiastici were published in 12 volumes in Rome, from 1598 to 1607. The present abridgment was compiled between the dates that are indicated at the beginning and at the end of this ms., between 1629 and 1633.
PRINTED DOCUMENTS.
95 printed broadsides and scrutiny lists with manuscript notes. Folio. Folded and double pages. Original limp vellum. Rome, 1579-1766.

This volume contains 90 broadsides of appointments of Cardinals by different Popes. With name, woodcut arms, and portraits, mostly printed in red and black, 1624-1766; also 5 printed scrutiny lists with notes by hand, 1597-1671.
FORTIGUERRI, NICCOLO. IL RICCIARDETTO
A poem in octaves, in 30 cantos. Ms. on paper. 197 ff. Folio. Contemporary limp vellum. N.pl., n.d.

Fortiguerri, Niccolo, Il Ricciardetto. A jocular poem: poema eroicomico in calligraphic writing with floral and ornamental title and head pieces at the beginning of each canto. Apparently, Forteguerri, as a result of a bet with friends, composed one canto a day.
